items.title: Prevotella copri promotes white adipose browning and ameliorates adiposity
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67327-x The gut microbiome can regulate diverse host metabolic processes, including thermogenesis in adipose tissues. Here, the authors report a reduced abundance of Prevotella copri in patients with obesity and its role in alleviating adiposity.

items.title: Photoelectrochemical water splitting cells at elevated pressure using BiVO<sub>4</sub> and platinized III-V semiconductor photoelectrodes
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67294-3 Many hydrogen applications require gas delivered under pressure. Here, the authors report that solar water-splitting devices can operate at up to 8 bar and show that the performance gains from elevated pressure depends critically on the choice of materials and device configuration.

items.title: Sequestration of the phagocyte metabolite itaconate by Pseudomonas aeruginosa RpoN promotes successful pulmonary infection
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67153-1 Itaconate is an airway metabolite released by phagocytes in response to infection. Here, the authors show that itaconate acts as a signal to simulate the adaptation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa to the lung by modifying RpoN through S-itaconation.

items.title: Phase-transition-driven ferroic response in 2D CuMnP<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>6</sub> under ultra-low electric fields
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67516-8 The authors predict 2D CuMnP2Se6 where a tiny electric field ( ~ 0.001 V/Å) flips in-plane polarization and switches magnetism from antiferromagnetic to ferromagnetic, enabling ultralow-power spintronic memories.

items.title: Spatial fluorescence barcode by transiently luminescent DNA beads
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67410-3 Fluorescence methods of multiplexed nucleic-acid detection are often limited by spectral overlap, nonspecific signals, and encoding capacity. Here the authors design a spatial fluorescence barcode platform which uses DNA beads for reusable multiplexed pathogen and cancer biomarker detection.

items.title: Substrate-adaptive sacrificial corrosion strategy enables 700 mV oxygen evolution window for enhanced seawater electrolysis
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67439-4 Seawater electrolysis for green hydrogen is hindered by corrosive chloride ions. Here, the authors report a substrate-adaptive sacrificial corrosion strategy for creating highly active anodes that resist seawater corrosion and break thermodynamic selectivity limits.

items.title: Evaluating transportability of in vitro cellular models to in vivo human phenotypes using gene perturbation data
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67199-1 The extent to which in-vitro cellular experiments are effective models for complex biology underlying human phenotypes is often unclear. Here the authors propose and implement a framework using gene perturbation data to evaluate in-vitro models.

items.title: Accumulation of Trehalose 6-Phosphate in Candidozyma auris results in Decreased Echinocandin Resistance and Tolerance
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67022-x Echinocandins are the first-line therapy for invasive Candidozyma auris infections, but the resistance to this drug is increasing. Here, the authors identify a potential target with a distinct mechanism of action for improving echinocandin treatment in C. auris.

items.title: Colloquium: The cosmic dipole anomaly
authors: Nathan Secrest, Sebastian von Hausegger, Mohamed Rameez, Roya Mohayaee, and Subir Sarkar
items.summary: The cosmological principle, which states that the Universe must be statistically isotropic and homogeneous on large scales, is a foundational principle of the standard model of cosmology, known as lambda cold dark matter ( Λ CDM). The validity of this principle can be tested by assessing the compatibility of a dipole anisotropy in the large-scale distribution of matter with the dipole observed in the cosmic microwave background, interpreted in the Λ CDM model as due to our local peculiar motion. This Colloquium describes the methodology for such a test and presents its outcome based on the analysis of recent large catalogs of radio galaxies and quasars, revealing a significant inconsistency between the two dipoles. The authors review these recent findings, as well as potential biases, systematic issues, and alternate interpretations, and discuss how this anomaly could challenge the standard description of our Universe based on the Λ CDM model. [Rev. Mod. Phys. 97, 041001] Published Thu Dec 11, 2025
